newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end down, spots up.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly down on Tuesday due to falls on the domestic A share markets, traders said.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day contract fell slightly to 8.88 percent from 9.00 percent on Monday.
Total turnover of the six-contract market fell to 5.8 million lots from 6.6 million.
One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Share prices on the Shanghai and Shenzhen A markets fell on Tuesday due to continued official warnings about the risks of stock investment, traders said.
The slide in A share prices was the major factor pulling down repo rates, especially the rates for early-maturing contracts, one trader.

The early-maturing contracts opened higher, supported by a new A share issue on the Shenzhen market, but the sharp falls on the A share markets pushed the rates down for the rest of the session, traders said.
Traders said they expected the contracts to move in a narrow range on Wednesday if the A share markets continue to be weak.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly up on Tuesday on good market sentiment, traders said.
The most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 rose to 118.09 yuan from 117.64 yuan.
Combined volume of the seven-contract market fell slightly to 1.2 million lots from 1.3 million lots.

Traders said sentiment was strong because of the liquidity recently injected into the market by state debt redemption. This helped spot contract prices to quickly recover from a technical correction on Monday, they said.
Traders said they expected prices to continue to rise in the next few days.
